India portal - Food portal - v - t - e **Masala dosa** ([Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language): மசாலா தோசை, [Kannada](/wiki/Kannada_language): ಮಸಾಲೆ ದೋಸೆ, *masāle dōse*y/dōsai) is a dish of [South India](/wiki/South_Indian_cuisine), consisting of a savoury [dosa](/wiki/Dosa_(food)) crepe stuffed with a spiced (*[masala](/wiki/Masala_(spice))*) potato curry. It is a popular breakfast item in South India, though it can be served at all times of the day and found in many other parts of the country and overseas. ## History It is generally agreed that the dish was popularized in Madras (now [Chennai](/wiki/Chennai)) during the 1930s by [K. Krishna Rao](/wiki/K._Krishna_Rao), a restaurateur who operated the popular [Udupi](/wiki/Udupi) style hotel called Sri Krishna Vilas Hotel on Mount Road and later the [New Woodlands Hotel](/wiki/New_Woodlands_Hotel), both pioneers of [Udupi cuisine](/wiki/Udupi_cuisine). Rao is also regarded as the dish's creator. One tale attributes it to the cooks of [Someshvara III](/wiki/Someshvara_III), [King of Mysore](/wiki/King_of_Mysore) (1126–1138), who combined leftover curry with dosas. However, while the *[Manasollasa](/wiki/Manasollasa)* compiled during his reign does mention a dosa-like dish called *dosaka*, potatoes are a [New World](/wiki/New_World) plant not introduced to India under the arrival of the Portuguese in the 16th century. ## Preparation While there is variation in the recipe from town to town, the basic recipe typically starts with a batter of parboiled [rice](/wiki/Rice), [poha](/wiki/Poha_(rice)), and various legumes ([black gram](/wiki/Black_gram), [pigeon peas](/wiki/Pigeon_peas), [chickpeas](/wiki/Chickpeas)), and incorporates various spices for flavour, such as [fenugreek](/wiki/Fenugreek) and dry red chilli. The rice and legumes are fermented by soaking them overnight in water, then ground into a batter. To make the dosa the batter is spread on a hot [tava](/wiki/Tava) griddle using a ladle or a bowl. It is pan-roasted until crispy, filled with potato curry, and served with [chutneys](/wiki/Chutney), and [sambar](/wiki/Sambar_(dish)). One common variant is the paper masala dosa, which is made with a thinner batter, resulting in a crisper, almost paper-thin final product. ## Variations
